DataElement.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the eye typically included in an ophthalmologic examination.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Determination of the visual capabilities of a person by completion of an ophthalmologic evaluation. [Manually-curated]

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A surgical specialty concerned with the structure and function of the eye and the medical and surgical treatment of its defects and diseases.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: A medical specialty concerned with the structure and function of the eye and the medical and surgical treatment of its defects and diseases.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Property.preferredDefinition: Complete; having every necessary or normal part or component or step; or having come or been brought to a conclusion.

Concepts.definition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A test performed by an ophthalmologist or optometrist assessing vision and ability to focus on and discern objects, as well as other tests and examinations pertaining to the eyes._Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A dome-shaped, transparent, avascular tissue covering the front of the eye. It is composed of five layers: squamous epithelium, Bowman's membrane, stroma, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium. Refraction of light contributing to eye's focusing ability is its characteristic function. It contains unmyelinated nerve endings which are responsible for the high sensitivity of the tissue.

Concepts.definition: A dome-shaped, transparent, avascular tissue covering the front of the eye. It is composed of five layers: squamous epithelium, Bowman's membrane, stroma, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium. Refraction of light contributing to eye's focusing ability is its characteristic function. It contains unmyelinated nerve endings which are responsible for the high sensitivity of the tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A light-sensitive membrane that lines the back wall of the eyeball. The retina is continuous with the optic nerve and this way transmits optical images to the brain.

Concepts.definition: A light-sensitive membrane that lines the back wall of the eyeball. The retina is continuous with the optic nerve and this way transmits optical images to the brain.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A biconvex transparent structure of the eye through which light is focused on the retina.  The lens sits behind the iris and is supported by the zonule, which connects it to the ciliary body.  The lens is an avascular structure.

Concepts.definition: A biconvex transparent structure of the eye through which light is focused on the retina. The lens sits behind the iris and is supported by the zonule, which connects it to the ciliary body. The lens is an avascular structure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin membrane of skin with the purpose of covering and protecting an eye.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: Anyone of the short hairs that grow on the edge of the eyelid.

Concepts.definition: A thin membrane of skin with the purpose of covering and protecting an eye.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Anyone of the short hairs that grow on the edge of the eyelid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The white, opaque, fibrous, outer tunic of the eyeball, covering it entirely excepting the segment covered anteriorly by the cornea. It is essentially avascular but contains apertures for vessels, lymphatics, and nerves. It receives the tendons of insertion of the extraocular muscles and at the corneoscleral junction contains the canal of Schlemm. (From Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)

Concepts.definition: The white, opaque, fibrous, outer tunic of the eyeball, covering it entirely excepting the segment covered anteriorly by the cornea. It is essentially avascular but contains apertures for vessels, lymphatics, and nerves. It receives the tendons of insertion of the extraocular muscles and at the corneoscleral junction contains the canal of Schlemm. (From Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The colored disc of the eye composed of connective tissue, epithelium, and endothelium. It separates the anterior chamber from the posterior chamber.

Concepts.definition: The colored disc of the eye composed of connective tissue, epithelium, and endothelium. It separates the anterior chamber from the posterior chamber.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The space in the eye, filled with aqueous humor, bounded anteriorly by the cornea and a small portion of the sclera and posteriorly by a small portion of the ciliary body, the iris, and that part of the crystalline lens which presents through the pupil. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed, p109)

Concepts.definition: The space in the eye, filled with aqueous humor, bounded anteriorly by the cornea and a small portion of the sclera and posteriorly by a small portion of the ciliary body, the iris, and that part of the crystalline lens which presents through the pupil. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed, p109)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin, transparent tissue divided into the palpebral conjunctiva (covering the inner side of the eye lid) and the bulbar conjunctiva (covering the eyeball).

Concepts.definition: A thin, transparent tissue divided into the palpebral conjunctiva (covering the inner side of the eye lid) and the bulbar conjunctiva (covering the eyeball).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.

Concepts.definition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An oval-shaped, yellow pigmented area located on the center of the retina, which contains a high density of cones for high-acuity vision, and which if damaged will result in the partial/complete loss of central vision.

Concepts.definition: A yellowish, highly pigmented, oval shaped area slightly lateral to the center of the retina of the eye which contains the fovea centralis and is mostly comprised of retinal cones, for high-acuity vision, and which if damaged will result in the partial/complete loss of central vision.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A portion of the retina at which the axons of the ganglion cells exit the eyeball to form the optic nerve. No light-sensitive photoreceptors are contained within this portion of the retina.

Concepts.definition: A portion of the retina at which the axons of the ganglion cells exit the eyeball to form the optic nerve. No light-sensitive photoreceptors are contained within this portion of the retina.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The nerve that carries messages from the retina to the brain.: An unusual or extreme paleness, state of decreased skin or mucosal coloration.

Concepts.definition: The second cranial nerve.
An unusual or extreme paleness, state of decreased skin or mucosal coloration.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The nerve that carries messages from the retina to the brain.

Concepts.definition: The second cranial nerve.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clear, avascular, gelatinous body that occupies the posterior chamber of the eye.  It is bounded by the retina except anteriorly where it lies adjacent to the lens and iris.

Concepts.definition: A clear, avascular, gelatinous body that occupies the posterior chamber of the eye.  It is bounded by the retina except anteriorly where it lies adjacent to the lens and iris.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tubular structure through which the blood circulates in the body. Blood vessels constitute a network composed of arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins.

Concepts.definition: A tubular structure through which the blood circulates in the body. Blood vessels constitute a network composed of arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated concept to reflect EVS definition_02.19.19

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A test performed by an ophthalmologist or optometrist assessing vision and ability to focus on and discern objects, as well as other tests and examinations pertaining to the eyes.:Named locations of or within the body.

Concepts.definition: A test performed by an ophthalmologist or optometrist assessing vision and ability to focus on and discern objects, as well as other tests and examinations pertaining to the eyes.
Named locations of or within the body.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Created to support NCI CCR visual exam field.12.29.2015.dmr

DataElement.changeDescription: Created to support NCI CCR clinical trials per request of Elizabeth Ness.12.29.2015.dmr
